raw_text:
Jamelia's return to the top
 
 R&B star Jamelia had three Brit nominations to go with her triple triumph at last year's Mobo awards.
 
 The Birmingham-born singer, full name Jamelia Davis, was signed to a record label at the age of 15 and released her first single So High at 18. She released four number ones from her 2000 album Drama, including the top five hit Money featuring the vocals of reggae artist Beenie Man. She racked up five Mobo nominations in 2000, winning one for best video. But in the same year she also fell pregnant and decided to take a break from music to bring up her daughter Teja, who was born in March 2001. While she originally planned to get back to work pretty swiftly after giving birth it was actually two years before she released another single. During her absence R&B music exploded and a whole host of female artists were on the scene, meaning Jamelia had to once again prove herself. Her comeback song Bout featuring Rah Digga only just scrapped into the top 40.
 
 It was her next single, Superstar, that really put her back on the map as one of Britain's most popular female R&B singers, holding her own in a music scene dominated by US artists such as Beyonce and Ashanti.
 
 Superstar was followed by Thank You, winner of best single at the 2004 Mobos, which reached number two in the UK charts. The autobiographical song, which deals with domestic abuse, hit number one in New Zealand and Australia. Next came the song See It In A Boy's Eyes, which was especially written for her by Coldplay's Chris Martin. His involvement with the song meant not only was it given massive publicity but it was also greeted favourably by a new audience who would not usually listen to R&B. She now combines singing with modelling and supporting charities including the NSPCC and Make Trade Fair. Despite her huge success in recent years, Jamelia remains down-to-earth about her fame and her chances of lasting in the fickle music business, partly due to motherhood. "When I first got into the industry, I'd be away from home for months at a time. But now I have other things in my life. I still want to make it, but it's not the end of the world if I don't," commented Jamelia.
llama3.2:1b: Jamelia Davis signed with a record label at 15 and released her first single So High in 2000.
She had five Mobo nominations that year, winning one for best video.
After giving birth to her daughter Teja in 2001, she took two years off from music, but returned with Superstar in 2002, which put her back on the map as a popular female R&B singer.
Her subsequent singles Thank You and See It In A Boy's Eyes both reached number one.

Jamelia combined singing and modelling after giving birth, supporting charities such as the NSPCC and Make Trade Fair, while also speaking about motherhood and not wanting to give up music despite it being a "fickle" industry.
llama3.2:3b: Jamelia Davis is an R&B singer who rose to fame as a teenager with hits like "Drama" and "Money".
After taking a break due to pregnancy, she returned to music two years later with the single "Superstar", which revitalized her career.
She continued to achieve success with singles like "Thank You" and "See It In A Boy's Eyes", while also combining singing with modeling and charity work.
gemma2:2b: Jamelia returned to music after a hiatus to raise her daughter.
Her comeback single "Superstar" brought her back into the spotlight and she followed up with successful singles such as "Thank You".
She has combined singing with modeling and charity work while remaining down-to-earth about the challenges of staying in the music business.
qwen2.5:0.5b: R&B star Jamelia had three Brit nominations and won one at the Mobo awards in 2001, including a top-five hit.
She released her first single "So High" at age 15 and released four number ones from her 2000 album Drama, including the top five hit Money featuring Beenie Man.
She struggled to prove herself after falling pregnant and decided to focus on taking care of her daughter.
Despite her comeback, she remains down-to-earth about her fame and plans for the future.
qwen2.5:1.5b: R&B singer Jamelia returned after leaving the music scene to prove herself again, becoming one of Britain's most popular female R&B singers with hits like Superstar and Thank You.
qwen2.5:3b: R&B singer Jamelia had three Brit nominations following her triple win at the 2000 Mobo awards.
At age 18, she released her first hit "So High" from her album "Drama."
She received five Mobo nominations in 2000 but took a two-year break to have and raise daughter Teja.
Her comeback single "Bout" only entered the top 40, while "Superstar," which followed, became popular enough to win Best Single at the 2004 Mobos.
"Thank You," another hit from this period, topped the charts in New Zealand and Australia.
Jamelia also worked with Coldplay's Chris Martin on "See It In A Boy's Eyes."
Despite her success, she remains grounded by her motherhood, prioritizing charity work alongside singing and modeling.
opencoder:1.5b:
Jamelia's return to the top

R&B star Jamelia had three Brit nominations to go with her triple triumph at last year's Mobo awards.
Jamelia was a Birmingham-born singer, and her first single, So High, was released on 18th March 2018.
She won five Mobo titles, one for best video, resulting in four number ones from her 2,000 albums, including the top five hit Money featuring the vocals of a reggae artist, Beenie Man.
Jamelia also racked up five Brit nominations to go with her triumph and three for best album.
She was also pregnant and had a daughter Teja who was born in March 2001.
Superstar by Rah Digga, released on 23rd March 2018, won number two in the UK charts and number one in Australia.
It was also an absolute hit on New Zealand with Chris Martin's song, which helped to amplify the success of the song.
Jamelia returned to her role as a R&B singer, but came back from her retirement to work at Coldplay, where she performed alongside other British artists like Beyonce and Ashanti.
She also supported various non-profit organizations such as NSPCC and Make Trade Fair.
Jamelia's success has been seen in recent years, with her reaching number four on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Her autobiographical song, "See It In A Boy's Eyes," was given massive publicity and had a new audience who might not have heard it at all.
Despite her huge success, she remains an advocate for motherhood in the music industry.
smollm:1.7b: Jamelia's return to the top was facilitated by her three Brit nominations and her triple triumph at last year's Mobo awards.
She also had a baby in March 2001 which delayed her release of another single for two years.
During this time, R&B music exploded and many female artists were on the scene, giving Jamelia an opportunity to prove herself once again.
Her comeback song Superstar was particularly well-received by the UK charts as it reached number two in New Zealand and Australia.
The autobiographical song Thank You was also given massive publicity due to its involvement with Chris Martin.
Jamelia's success in recent years has been driven by her ability to combine singing with modelling and supporting charities including the NSPCC and Make Trade Fair.
Despite her huge success, Jamelia remains down-to-earth about her fame and her chances of lasting in the fickle music business, partly due to motherhood.
She still wants to make it, but it's not the end of the world if she doesn't.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Jamelia returned to R&B after three nominations, facing challenges with pregnancy before raising her daughter.
She released "Superstar" and was top 50, followed by "Thank You."
She's back despite baby issues but continues to work, modeling and charity.
She cares about fame due to new child.
tinyllama:1.1b: Jamelia (R&B singer) returned to the top following her pregnancy and maternity leave with three Brit nominations, including winning one for best video.
She took a break from music to raise her daughter Teja and after two years, returned with new single Superstar that quickly soared into the UK charts and won best single at the 2004 MoBo's.

Jamelia's comeback song Boubé featured Rah Digga only just scrapped into the top 40, but she managed to hold her own in a music scene dominated by US artists such as Beyonce and Ashanti with Superstar winning best single at the 2004 MoBos.
Her upcoming album Soon features an unreleased song written for Coldplay's Chris Martin, which was given favorable publicity but also met with criticism due to a new audience not listening to R&B.
Despite her fame and the chaos of staying in the industry, Jamelia remains down-to-earth about her successes and the challenges of maintaining a household.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Jamelia Davis, born and raised in Birmingham, England, made her mark on the music scene as a teenage star with hits that went multi-platinum.
In 2001, she was nominated for three Brit Awards and won one with So High, which featured the vocals of Jamaican reggae star Beenie Man.
Over the years, Jamelia has released several successful singles, including Superstar, which reached number two in the UK charts and earned her a Mobo Award for Best Single.
Her most recent single is Thank You, which not only reached number one in New Zealand but also reached number two in Australia and was written especially for her by Coldplay's Chris Martin.
Despite her success, Jamelia remains down-to-earth about her fame and her chances of lasting in the industry due to motherhood.
phi:2.7b: R&B singer Jamelia had three nominations at last year's Mobo awards, but she took a break from music for two years after getting pregnant with her daughter Teja.
When she returned to music, she proved herself by releasing Superstar which became one of Britain's most popular female R&B singers.
Her success was marked by another hit single, Thank You which won best single at the 2004 Mobos and reached number two in UK charts.
Jamelia is now down-to-earth about her fame and is also a model who supports charities like the NSPCC and Make Trade Fair.
orca-mini:3b: Jamelia returned to the top of her game with three Brit nominations and a Mobo win for best video, while maintaining her status as one of Britain's most popular female R&B singers.
Her comeback song Bout featuring Rah Digga only just scraped into the top 40, but it was Superstar that really put her back on the map.
Thank You, winner of best single at the 2004 Mobos, reached number two in the UK charts and was followed by See It In A Boy's Eyes, written by Coldplay's Chris Martin.
Jamelia remains humble about her success and enjoys balancing singing with modelling and supporting charities such as the NSPCC and Make Trade Fair.
Despite the fickle nature of the music business, she remains determined to make it in the industry.
hermes3:3b: Jamilia Davis, R&B star, returned to top with Brit nominations after Mobo triple win in 2001.
Released successful albums including 'Drama' and 'Thank You'.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Jamelia, an R&B star, returned to the top after taking a break from music for two years to focus on her pregnancy and daughter.
She released several successful singles, including "Superstar" and "Thank You," which reached number two in UK charts and dealt with domestic abuse respectively.
Jamelia now combines singing with modelling and supporting charities.
Despite her recent success, she remains grounded about her enduring fame and the challenges of staying relevant in the music business as a mother.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Jamelia, the Birmingham-born R&B singer, rose to fame with her 2000 album *Drama*, earning multiple Mobo nominations and a win.
However, she took a break from music after becoming a mother in 2001.
Her comeback was initially slow, but her single *Superstar* reestablished her as a leading British R&B artist.
She followed it with *Thank You*, which won Best Single at the 2004 Mobos and topped charts in New Zealand and Australia.
*See It In A Boy’s Eyes*, written for her by Coldplay’s Chris Martin, expanded her audience.
Alongside her music career, she engages in modeling and charity work.
Despite her success, Jamelia remains grounded, balancing fame with motherhood and acknowledging the uncertainties of the music industry.
stablelm2:1.6b: R&B star Jamelia had multiple Brit nominations and awards before her pregnancy break.
She released four number ones from her album Drama and won a MOBO award for best video.
Her return to the top began with "Bout" featuring Rah Digga.
Her next single, "Superstar," dominated UK charts after winning best single at MOBOs.
Followed by "Thank You," which reached number two in the UK, followed by "See It In A Boy' s Eyes," a song specifically written for Jamelia by Coldplay's Chris Martin.
She also supports charities like NSPCC and Make Trade Fair alongside her successful singing career.
Despite her success, Jamelia remains grounded and dedicated to motherhood.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Jamelia, born Jamelia Davis in Birmingham, is a successful R&B singer who began her career at 15 and released her debut single "So High" at 18.
Her 2000 album "Drama" yielded four number-one hits, including the top five hit "Money," earning her Mobo nominations.
However, she took a two-year hiatus to raise her daughter Teja.
Upon returning in 2002, she faced competition from dominant US R&B artists like Beyonce and Ashanti.
Her comeback single, "Bout," just missed the top 40.
Jamelia's breakthrough came with "Superstar," which reached number two in the UK and topped in New Zealand and Australia.

She followed this with "Thank You," a best-single winner at the 2004 Mobos, and "See It In A Boy's Eyes," co-written by Coldplay's Chris Martin, which gained new audience attention due to his involvement.
Jamelia also models and supports charities like NSPCC and Make Trade Fair.
Despite her success, she remains grounded, acknowledging that motherhood influences her priorities and managing fame's unpredictability is crucial for lasting in the music industry.
